XQsThaiPoes

Does evolution conflict with sin? This is not a classic vs. creation debate. Both evolution and creation get to be viewed as facts regardless of conflicts with in the scope of the thread.
 
 Darwin was a religious man in his youth. He had a painful stomach condition. When his daughter Annie died at ten he attributed it to passing his weakness on to her, and his faith in evolution was sealed.I know this is not a direct cause and effect, and don't take it as such. This is already laid out in the bible. Animals are meant to die. People are not. Man was reduced to the level of animals after he sinned. So there is no divine intervention outside of Christ ransom to save her from dying from bad genes or disease.

post_info.post_title: Are Sin and Evolution the same phenomena?

Ursus maritimus

As an atheist, I don't believe in sin, so I would say there is no connection nor conflict between evolution and sin.
 
 Perhaps a theistic evolutionist would like to comment?
unkerpaulie

strictly by word definition, "sin" is "transgression of God's law" as described in the Bible. in fact, the Bible is the only source of the law of God, and therefore the definition of sin. "sin" can only really only apply to those who believe that the Bible is entirely true (i.e., the laws that are allegedly God's laws are in fact God's laws)
 
 the theory of evolution directly condradictory to the story of creation in Genesis
 
 the problem is, if evolution is indeed true, then the story in Genesis is false. and if Genesis is false, then the Bible is not entirely true. and if the Bible is not entirely true, there is reason to doubt that any other feats of God as stated in the Bible (including describing his law, and even inspiring man for that matter). and if we doubt that the Bible was God's inspired word to man, then its just a book with a bunch of stories.
 
 its like a domino effect
 
 so far the validity of the theory of evolution is questionable, and creationists and christians on a whole are clinging to this.
 
 I think creation has finally met its match, and both are on a more-or-less even playing field. creationists assert that creation is a fact, evolutionists assert that evolution is a fact, and neither of the two can really dominate as far as evidence, so both are "theories with holes". accepting creation or evolution has come down to a matter of personal belief rather than based on solid truth, as far as I see
Void

the problem is, if evolution is indeed true, then the story in Genesis is false. and if Genesis is false, then the Bible is not entirely true
 
 Or perhaps Genesis is a moral story and isn't supposed to be a literal event. In which case the Bible remains true. In fact many Christians, Jews and Muslims take this view.
unkerpaulie

Or perhaps Genesis is a moral story and isn't supposed to be a literal event. In which case the Bible remains true. In fact many Christians, Jews and Muslims take this view.
 
 and then what else can be taken as just a "moral story"? the flood? the plagues? the Red Sea crossing? the writing of the Tablets? all the miracles of the Old Testament?
 
 first of all, the story of creation does more than explain how the world came to be. more importantly than that, the Genesis story purports that God has unlimited power, and that man has sinned and are in need of redemption. 
 
 If we cant take the events as literal, then I guess God didnt create the world and all life in 7 days, there was no garden of eden, no Adam, no Eve, no fruit, no snake. its not literal, just a moral story. then I guess mankind never really "fell". and I guess God doesnt really have that kind of power either. so what really is the moral of the story?
 
 Genesis is not just a story in the Bible, it is the foundation of everything in the Bible. what good is a God that we dont need to save us? what good is a God that cant create the world, and how is he going to create heaven? will heaven be created from a atom-sized ball of mass exploding too?
 
 you better believe that without the Genesis story being an actual event, the Bible is little more than useless...
The Barbarian

The notion that man was never meant to die a physical death is completely unscriptural.
 
 In fact, after Adam eats from the tree, God Himself expresses concern that he might then become immortal...
 
 Genesis 3:22  And the LORD God said, Behold, the man is become as one of us, to know good and evil: and now, lest he put forth his hand, and take also of the tree of life, and eat, and live for ever:
 
 An orthodox reading of Genesis does not include the assumption that man was meant to be immortal in his physical body.
unkerpaulie

from what I understand is that God told Adam in the first place "any tree in the garden you nay eat of (including the fruit of the tree of life), but the day you eat of that fruit (of the knowledge of good and evil) you will surely die" (paraphrased). this implies that man wasnt obligated to die if the fruit wasnt eaten.
 
 however, once they had eaten of fruit of the knowledge of good and evil, they lost theit immortality. So God prevented them from eating from the tree of life to regain their immortality. if they had gotten to the tree of life they would have in effect "outsmarted" God, because they had eaten the fruit of good and evil, and effectively sentenced themselves to death, and if they ate of the tree of life, it would nullify the death sentence and prove God wrong...
Void

The flood is not an original biblical story, it existed in a far less exagerated form hundreds of years before the old testament was written. It was included into the old testament and names and descriptions were changed.
unkerpaulie

The flood is not an original biblical story, it existed in a far less exagerated form hundreds of years before the old testament was written. It was included into the old testament and names and descriptions were changed.

 according to Bible scholars, the Book of Genesis was written by Moses. so its no mystery that everything that happened in the book of Genesis would have been hundreds or even thousand of years before the Old Testament was written. Moses was only born in Exodus 2.
 
 I dont get your point. Are the stories in the book of Genesis (and all the miracles of the Old Testament) to be considered as factual historical events or moral stories?

 so far the validity of the theory of evolution is questionable, and creationists and christians on a whole are clinging to this.
 
 I think creation has finally met its match, and both are on a more-or-less even playing field. creationists assert that creation is a fact, evolutionists assert that evolution is a fact, and neither of the two can really dominate as far as evidence, so both are "theories with holes". accepting creation or evolution has come down to a matter of personal belief rather than based on solid truth, as far as I see

 
 While that definition of sin is true, the Hebrew definition means missing the mark. You could stretch it to mean unfit in English.
 
 And you're technically wrong about the bible. Modernly it is one book, but bible means little books. For a time they were floating around in clusters. So academically they are self contained and unrelated. The apocryphal books are "secret" books. Religious scholars eventually decided they were just a bunch of stories, and most never made it in the bible. Look at Song of Solomon it made the cut, and people still have problems with it being put in, yet it conflicts with nothing.
XQsThaiPoes

The notion that man was never meant to die a physical death is completely unscriptural.
 
 In fact, after Adam eats from the tree, God Himself expresses concern that he might then become immortal...
 
 Genesis 3:22  And the LORD God said, Behold, the man is become as one of us, to know good and evil: and now, lest he put forth his hand, and take also of the tree of life, and eat, and live for ever:
 
 An orthodox reading of Genesis does not include the assumption that man was meant to be immortal in his physical body.

 
 I am confused, but Adam was not really "immortal". He just did not age. The tree was put under guard to keep Satan from causing more damage. Satan is "father of the lie" if they ate the tree of life God would be forced to lie or show he really is not sovereign. Satan probably didn't think God was the violent type, and didn't expect guys with AR-15s babysitting a bush.
 
 Also the fruit may have not had any real physical power biochemicaly speaking. Just Gods word behind them. It is like the ark it was just a gold box, but if you touched it deliberately or not; you would die.

the problem is, if evolution is indeed true, then the story in Genesis is false. and if Genesis is false, then the Bible is not entirely true
 
 Or perhaps Genesis is a moral story and isn't supposed to be a literal event. In which case the Bible remains true. In fact many Christians, Jews and Muslims take this view.

 
 
 Without the Fall, Jesus would have no need to come to earth and be resurrected. Without Genesis, the entire bible-as-literal kinda falls apart.
Pooeypants

The flood is not an original biblical story, it existed in a far less exagerated form hundreds of years before the old testament was written. It was included into the old testament and names and descriptions were changed.

 Indeed, I mean we have things like a revamped gilgamesh VS the most supported scientific theory (more certain than gravity infact)...what challenge is there?
lurch

according to Bible scholars, the Book of Genesis was written by Moses.

 Actually not. Anyone who claims that Genesis was written by Moses isn't a Bible scholar. That is merely an unsupported tradition that is certainly not true.
 
 This is from the Introduction to the Old Testament at the front of a Bible.
 
Despite its unity of plan and purpose, the book (Genesis) is a complex work, not to be attributed to a single original author. Several sources, or literary traditions, that the final redactor used in his composition are discernible. These are the Yahwist, Elohist and Priestly sources, which in turn reflect older oral traditions.

 The separate traditions are evident with only a cursory reading of the 1st 11 chapters. There are two versions of creation, one where the gods are plural ("Let Us make man in our image.") There are also two intermixed versions of the flood myth, which is why there is so much repetition in that story.
XQsThaiPoes

Actually not. Anyone who claims that Genesis was written by Moses isn't a Bible scholar. That is merely an unsupported tradition that is certainly not true.
 
 This is from the Introduction to the Old Testament at the front of a Bible.

There are also two intermixed versions of the flood myth, which is why there is so much repetition in that story.

 
 Um I don't get it. Are you saying that moses didn't know the other traditions?
thebootfitter

Has anybody ever read any of Daniel Quinn's books?
 
 Specifically, in 'The Story of B,' I think he poses a very interesting question that perhaps, just perhaps, the 'Fall' came approximately 10,000 years ago when humans started living a totalitarian agricultural lifestyle. I don't want to go into details, but I'd encourage anyone to read the book. Very interesting indeed!
lurch

Are you saying that moses didn't know the other traditions?
The tradition is that Moses wrote the first 5 books of the Bible (I think). If that is true, then he wrote about his own death. Actually, the claim that Moses wrote parts of the Bible it is nothing more than myth. Genesis especially had several authors. The structure of the language is different, different vocabulary is used, and even the gods go from singular to plural.
 
 So what I am saying is that Moses didn't write Genesis - several authors did. We don't know what Moses knew - and that presumes that there really was a Moses.
 
 My actual remarks were directed to the claim that Bible scholars claim that the Genesis was written by Moses. In fact, Bible scholars claim quite the opposite. Those who claim otherwise are merely readers of the Bible. And that pretty much crosses the boundaries of religion or religious sect.
